head.title: HOBBIT Solitaire

div.div: In HOBBIT Solitaire you are moving cards from the three piles on the left to the three piles on the right. You can only move a card onto a pile on the right if it defeats the top card on the pile.

HOBBIT Solitaire uses the standard HOBBIT card strength and point system: Kings are the strongst, followed by queens, aces, 10s, 9s, 8s, then 7s. Hwaiet King of Hearts, B'shenzy•Boo Quean of Diamonds, and Tanner Ace of Spades are always high trump, stronger than the king of the current trump suit.
A trump card will always win against a non-trump card. In HOBBIT Solitaire, the three high trump cards "complete" a pile so that you can re-start playing on it.

At the beginning of the game, before any jacks have been placed onto the Jack Stack, there is no trump suit. Then, whenever a jack is placed onto the Jack Stack, its suit becomes trump. The changing of the trump suit also opens up new possibilities for moving cards onto piles that were previously inaccessible.

By the way, the source code for this page—along with licensing terms for its use—can be viewed by using your web browser's "view source" feature. (Long story, short: The game is a single, self-contained xml file. You may view, use, modify, and distribute it under the terms of the GNU Affero General Public License).
Play continues until all cards have been moved to the piles on the right, or else discarded. You do not get points for discarded cards.

Once again the standard HOBBIT card strength and point system applies: Sevens and nines are worth 5 points, jacks are worth jack (0 points), and everything else is worth 1 point. This makes a total of 60 points.
In HOBBIT Solitaire, 55 points or more is considered a win. This means you can only discard up to five one-point cards OR one five-point card. Or you can get all 60 points for a perfect score!

div.button: Got it. Let's start the game.

div.div: Remember, the jacks will change the trump suit and Tanner Ace of Spades will finish and restart a pile. The last card is a random card from the deck that you will need to be prepared to play... or else take your chances (once you flip over a card you must play it next).
